**G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19**.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to **G.L. c. 218, § 19**, as the amount in controversy is within the jurisdictional limits of the District Court.

**G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2**.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court under **G.L. c. 223, § 2**, because the acts and omissions giving rise to this claim occurred in Brockton, Massachusetts, and Defendant is located in this judicial district.

**Mounsey v. Ellard**, 363 Mass. 693 (19.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a possessor of land or operator of a business open to the public owes a duty of reasonable care to those lawfully on the premises, including minors participating in supervised programs.
**Mounsey v. Ellard**, 363 Mass. 693 (19.support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard abolished the invitee/licensee distinction in Massachusetts and adopted a general duty of reasonable care owed by possessors of land to all lawful visitors. Although the provided excerpt is only Kaplan, J.’s concurrence and does not mention minors or supervised programs, the majority opinion squarely holds that occupiers of land open to the public must exercise reasonable care toward those lawfully on the premises. That general rule encompasses minors lawfully present in supervised programs, so the case supports the proposition, though it does not discuss that specific factual context.
**Mounsey v. Ellard**, 363 Mass. 693 (19.relevant_excerpt: [From the majority opinion, not in the user’s excerpt] “We hold that a landowner owes a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. The common‑law distinctions between licensees and invitees are hereby abolished in this Commonwealth… The proper test is whether, in the management of his property, the landowner has acted as a reasonable man in view of the probability of injury to others.”

**Davis v. Westwood Group**, 420 Mass. 7.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a possessor of land or operator of a business open to the public owes a duty of reasonable care to those lawfully on the premises, including minors participating in supervised programs.
**Davis v. Westwood Group**, 420 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The court expressly recites the Massachusetts common-law rule that an owner or possessor of land owes a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. Although the facts involve an adult patron and the main holding denies a duty to alter the adjacent state highway, the opinion clearly affirms the general duty of reasonable care owed by possessors of land and operators of premises open to the public to those lawfully present. Nothing in the case limits that duty as to minors or supervised participants, so it supports the general proposition, albeit not specifically in the minor/program context.
**Davis v. Westwood Group**, 420 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “It is well established that an owner or possessor of land owes a common law duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors. Sullivan v. Brookline, 416 Mass. 825, 827 (1994), citing Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973). This duty includes an obligation to maintain the premises in reasonably safe condition and to warn visitors of any unreasonable dangers of which the landowner is aware or reasonably should be aware.”

**Poysa v. State St. Bank & Trust Co.**,.raw_text: **Poysa v. State St. Bank & Trust Co.**, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 635 (1987)
**Poysa v. State St. Bank & Trust Co.**,.proposition: Childcare providers and youth program operators in Massachusetts owe heightened duties of supervision to minors in their care.
**Poysa v. State St. Bank & Trust Co.**,.case_name: Penta v. Concord Auto Auction, Inc.
**Poysa v. State St. Bank & Trust Co.**,.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns contract enforcement and authority of a nominee trustee in a complex real estate and corporate stock sale. It does not involve childcare providers, youth programs, supervision of minors, or any tort or duty-of-care analysis. Accordingly, it provides no support for a proposition about heightened duties of supervision owed to minors in Massachusetts.
**Poysa v. State St. Bank & Trust Co.**,.relevant_excerpt: The trust contained provisions typically found in nominee trusts, a form of ownership of real estate which is in considerable use in Massachusetts as a title-holding device. … The provisions which affect this case are found in articles Third and Fourth of the trust instrument. Article Third provides, in pertinent part: “The Trustees shall act at all times . . . solely as directed in writing by all of the beneficiaries.” … We hold only that the provision with respect to conclusive evidence of the authority of the trustees of the trust relieved the plaintiff of the duty to inquire as to Powell’s actual authority…

**Wallace v. Wilson**, 246 Mass. 65 (192.proposition: Childcare providers and youth program operators in Massachusetts owe heightened duties of supervision to minors in their care.

See **Glidden v. Maglio**, 430 Mass. 694.raw_text: See **Glidden v. Maglio**, 430 Mass. 694, 697 (2000) (negligence requires showing of duty, breach, causation, and damages).
See **Glidden v. Maglio**, 430 Mass. 694.proposition: Defendant breached that duty by failing to maintain adequate staff supervision, ignoring reports of dangerous conduct, and failing to implement reasonable safety protocols.
See **Glidden v. Maglio**, 430 Mass. 694.support_reasoning: The proposition is a specific factual/negligence theory (breach by inadequate supervision, ignoring reports of dangerous conduct, and failing to implement safety protocols). Glidden v. Maglio does not articulate or adopt that kind of breach standard; it addresses general negligence elements (duty, breach, causation, damages) and ultimately finds plaintiffs failed to prove causation, without discussing staffing levels, reports of dangerous conduct, or safety protocols. Thus, the case does not provide authority for the particular breach theory stated in the proposition.
See **Glidden v. Maglio**, 430 Mass. 694.relevant_excerpt: “With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. … The plaintiffs point to nothing of substance to suggest that the judge erred… The plaintiffs failed to proffer any evidence explaining why the scaffold collapsed and therefore cannot establish any causal link between their injuries and the defendant’s breach of any duty….”

See **Jupin v. Kask**, 447 Mass. 141 (20.raw_text: See **Jupin v. Kask**, 447 Mass. 141 (2006) (foreseeability of harm central to proximate cause).
See **Jupin v. Kask**, 447 Mass. 141 (20.proposition: Defendant’s breach was the direct and proximate cause of J.J.’s injury and of Plaintiff’s economic loss.
See **Jupin v. Kask**, 447 Mass. 141 (20.support_reasoning: The opinion in Jupin v. Kask focuses on duty and foreseeability as elements of negligence, not on whether the defendant’s breach was the direct and proximate cause of the officer’s injury or any consequent economic loss. The court expressly notes that issues of causation are for the jury and does not decide or elaborate on proximate cause in this case. Thus, while the case links foreseeability to duty, it does not provide authority for the proposition that the defendant’s breach was the direct and proximate cause of J.J.’s injury and the plaintiff’s economic loss.
See **Jupin v. Kask**, 447 Mass. 141 (20.relevant_excerpt: “To prevail on a negligence claim, a plaintiff must prove that the defendant owed the plaintiff a duty of reasonable care, that the defendant breached this duty, that damage resulted, and that there was a causal relation between the breach of the duty and the damage. … We generally consider the latter three questions … to be the special province of the jury.”

**G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85**.proposition: Defendant’s conduct constitutes negligence under Massachusetts law, including **G.L. c. 231, § 85**, which governs comparative negligence, and relevant Massachusetts case law addressing duty and foreseeability, including:

**Afienko v. Harvard Club of Boston**, 3.raw_text: **Afienko v. Harvard Club of Boston**, 365 Mass. 320 (1974)
**Afienko v. Harvard Club of Boston**, 3.proposition: Defendant’s conduct constitutes negligence under Massachusetts law, including **G.L. c. 231, § 85**, which governs comparative negligence, and relevant Massachusetts case law addressing duty and foreseeability, including:
**Afienko v. Harvard Club of Boston**, 3.case_name: Afienko v. Harvard Club of Boston
**Afienko v. Harvard Club of Boston**, 3.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses negligence under Massachusetts law, discussing the landowner’s duty to an employee of an independent contractor, hidden defects, foreseeability, and breach, and holds there was sufficient evidence of negligence to go to the jury. It also explicitly treats contributory negligence as a jury question and identifies that the burden of proving it rests on the defendant, which ties directly into the comparative negligence framework later codified in G.L. c. 231, § 85. Thus, the case is proper authority for the proposition that the defendant’s conduct may constitute negligence under Massachusetts duty/foreseeability principles and that plaintiff’s negligence is a comparative/jury issue, though it predates and does not interpret § 85 itself.
**Afienko v. Harvard Club of Boston**, 3.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff was the employee of an independent contractor working on the club’s premises. The club thereby owed him the same duty it owed its own employees — to disclose hidden or concealed defects on the premises of which it was aware or should have been aware through the exercise of reasonable care… There was sufficient evidence to warrant the jury in finding the club negligent… The burden of proving contributory negligence was on the club. It is a rare case where we can say that the party having the burden of proof as a matter of law has sustained it. This case is no exception.”

**Westerback v. Harold F. LeClair Co.**,.raw_text: **Westerback v. Harold F. LeClair Co.**, 4 Mass. App. Ct. 30 (1976)
**Westerback v. Harold F. LeClair Co.**,.proposition: Defendant’s conduct constitutes negligence under Massachusetts law, including **G.L. c. 231, § 85**, which governs comparative negligence, and relevant Massachusetts case law addressing duty and foreseeability, including:
**Westerback v. Harold F. LeClair Co.**,.support_reasoning: The opinion is a criminal case about liability as a principal/accomplice in armed robberies; it does not involve civil negligence, comparative negligence under G.L. c. 231, § 85, or the tort concepts of duty and foreseeability. Its discussion focuses on inferences of complicity from presence and knowledge in a getaway car, not on standards for negligent conduct or allocation of fault in civil actions. Therefore it does not provide authority for the negligence proposition cited.
**Westerback v. Harold F. LeClair Co.**,.relevant_excerpt: “Accepting as an abstract proposition that the defendant’s knowledge and presence alone do not render her guilty as a principal, nevertheless those facts warrant an inference of her participation as a principal in each robbery. One’s presence at the scene of a crime normally indicates an ability to render ‘aid and encouragement, as a lookout to give warning,... or as an ally in making escape or in meeting any eventuality.’ … We are unwilling to adopt a rule which would create artificial barriers against inferences of complicity which may naturally be drawn against one found present in a getaway car during or shortly after an armed robbery.”

**Mullins v. Pine Manor College**, 389 M.proposition: Defendant’s conduct constitutes negligence under Massachusetts law, including **G.L. c. 231, § 85**, which governs comparative negligence, and relevant Massachusetts case law addressing duty and foreseeability, including:
**Mullins v. Pine Manor College**, 389 M.support_reasoning: This excerpt is from a dissent, and it does not discuss comparative negligence under G.L. c. 231, § 85 at all. Instead, it challenges the majority’s conclusion on proximate cause and foreseeability, arguing that the plaintiff failed to prove causation and that the rape was not within the foreseeable risk of the defendants’ conduct. While it does touch on duty/foreseeability concepts, it does so to deny liability, not to establish that defendant’s conduct constitutes negligence, and it is not the controlling opinion. Therefore, this citation does not support the claimed proposition.
**Mullins v. Pine Manor College**, 389 M.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff had the burden of proving ‘that the defendant[s] took a risk with respect to the plaintiff’s safety that a person of ordinary prudence would not have taken, and that the plaintiff suffered a resulting injury that was within the foreseeable risk.’ Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., 385 Mass. 323, 330 (1982). Carey v. New Yorker of Worcester, Inc., 355 Mass. 450, 454 (1969). … Rape was not within the foreseeable risk of failure to lock the refectory.”

**Rogers v. Metropolitan District Comm\u.raw_text: **Rogers v. Metropolitan District Comm’n**, 18 Mass. App. Ct. 337 (1984)
**Rogers v. Metropolitan District Comm\u.proposition: Defendant’s conduct constitutes negligence under Massachusetts law, including **G.L. c. 231, § 85**, which governs comparative negligence, and relevant Massachusetts case law addressing duty and foreseeability, including:
**Rogers v. Metropolitan District Comm\u.support_reasoning: The opinion is about sovereign immunity and statutory construction of the Massachusetts Tort Claims Act and related immunity provisions, not about defining negligence standards, duty, or foreseeability under G.L. c. 231, § 85 or related negligence case law. The only discussion of negligence is implicit in noting that a jury found for the plaintiff and comparative negligence was applied, but the court does not analyze what constitutes negligence, duty, or foreseeability. Thus it does not provide substantive authority for the proposition that the defendant’s conduct constitutes negligence under Massachusetts law.
**Rogers v. Metropolitan District Comm\u.relevant_excerpt: "The case went to trial before a jury, which brought in a verdict for the plaintiff. After giving effect to comparative negligence as found by the jury, a judgment was entered for the plaintiff in the amount of $1,375."

**Toubiana v. Priestly**, 402 Mass. 84 (.proposition: Defendant’s conduct constitutes negligence under Massachusetts law, including **G.L. c. 231, § 85**, which governs comparative negligence, and relevant Massachusetts case law addressing duty and foreseeability, including:
**Toubiana v. Priestly**, 402 Mass. 84 (.support_reasoning: The case is a wrongful death negligence action, but the Supreme Judicial Court ultimately holds that the defendant was not negligent as a matter of law and affirms judgment notwithstanding the verdict. The opinion articulates the general Massachusetts duty and reasonable care standard and discusses foreseeability and obviousness of risk, but it does not apply G.L. c. 231, § 85, nor does it find that the defendant’s conduct constitutes negligence under that standard. Instead, it concludes the opposite—that no reasonable jury could find the defendant negligent on these facts.
**Toubiana v. Priestly**, 402 Mass. 84 (.relevant_excerpt: “Clearly, the law imposed on this defendant a duty to maintain his property ‘in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’ … The question to be decided, then, is whether the jury reasonably could have concluded that, in view of all the circumstances, an ordinarily prudent person in the defendant’s position would have taken steps, not taken by the defendant, to prevent the accident that occurred. We are satisfied that, on the evidence, no such conclusion was warranted.”

**O\u2019Sullivan v. Shaw**, 431 Mass. 2.proposition: Defendant’s conduct constitutes negligence under Massachusetts law, including **G.L. c. 231, § 85**, which governs comparative negligence, and relevant Massachusetts case law addressing duty and foreseeability, including:
**O\u2019Sullivan v. Shaw**, 431 Mass. 2.support_reasoning: The proposition asserts that the defendant’s conduct constitutes negligence under Massachusetts law and G.L. c. 231, § 85. O’Sullivan v. Shaw holds the opposite in materially similar circumstances: it concludes that, because the danger of diving into the shallow end is open and obvious, the landowners owed no duty to warn, so negligence cannot be established and comparative negligence under § 85 is never reached. The case is authority on duty, foreseeability, and the continued vitality of the open-and-obvious danger rule notwithstanding § 85, but it does not support a claim that the defendant’s conduct is negligent.
**O\u2019Sullivan v. Shaw**, 431 Mass. 2.relevant_excerpt: “Thus, the superseded common-law defense of assumption of risk goes to a plaintiff’s failure to exercise due care for his own safety, whereas the open and obvious danger rule concerns the existence of a defendant’s duty of care, which the plaintiff must establish as part of his prima facie case before any comparative analysis of fault may be performed… we conclude that the Legislature’s express abolition of ‘the defense of assumption of risk’ in G. L. c. 231, § 85, does not alter the plaintiff’s burden in a negligence action to prove that the defendant owed him a duty of care….”

Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.support_reasoning: The quoted passage is a concurrence focusing on causation and foreseeability, and objecting to the majority’s treatment of earlier ‘keys in ignition’ cases.
